title: Ask HN: How to get back into tech after two years of absence because of burnout?
text:
So I did not do anything coding or technical for the past two years because of severe burnout. Instead, I chose to become an engineering manager because it was a much different career path and this was really helping me get over the coding burnout that I've accumulated over the years.

I feel that I'm at a stage of my life where I can code again and move back to the IC path. Not that I dislike management, I just like being an IC more. My technical skills are very rusty, like I can probably system design my way through but will struggle initially writing code again.

But since that's my goal, I need a bit of advice in terms of how to "get back" into the industry after effectively being gone for 2 years as an IC? My current strategy is to do what I did before (choose a language, do leetcode, do sideprojects, join community, read books, etc, etc) but I'm confused about whether I should be specialising at my age or not? Specialisation for me means to either go into a specific industry (crypto, self driving, etc) or specialising like become a SRE, Data Engineer, etc.

Personal context (if stats matters): 37 yrs, 15 yrs tech industry experience. Last language I used before burnout was Go.

Show HN: Selaro Personal/Workplace knowledge management tool
text:
Hi HN!

I built Selaro to make things easier to find at work. It works as an auto bookmark tool based on URLs to sites that I visit. Often these are pages like confluence pages, github repos etc and bookmarking these individually is a lot of organization and effort.

The permissions needed are wide since it works based on your URLs visited. I haven't found a better workaround for this yet. The tool stores all your data locally and uses no remote database except for Auth/signup (optional).

It's not a full fledged knowledge management, but this is the scoped down MVP. Open to feedback on the product and also path forward for it.

title: Yorlang Programming Language

Best resources for an engineer to learn databases?
text:
I’ve picked up a few programming languages by now, and I feel pretty comfortable understanding the differences (garbage collection, interpreter vs compiler, type systems, etc.)

Im at a point now where I feel like I “know” programming languages and could pick up a new one or choose the appropriate one for a project without a ton of effort

But for databases- I know a little bit, but i wouldn’t really know how to start choosing a database, or moving business logic like replication or rpc calls into a database.

Does anybody know a good resource? I see lots of courses online targeted at DBAs, Im not sure if that’s where I should start, or if I should do hello worlds or some equivalent of leetcode like I do for picking up a new language

title: Ask HN: Transitioning to consulting
text:
Dear HN,

As a long time lurker I've come to seek the collective wisdom of this august assembly.

I've been a FTE for the entirety of my so far 6 year career, but am looking to switch over to consulting. I'm targeting B2B, fully remote engagements.

My skillset is varied with strong C++ and Python, as applied to backend engineering, as well as having done research work in ML/AI and quant spaces. Based on informal chats with my network I'm able to get assignments quite easily, but not necessarily within my areas of specialization.

I'm trying to figure out how to strategize around this transition and am looking for some advice. Here are my main questions:

  Are there any recommended resources (Books/blogs/courses/etc.) I should look into?
  Do I focus on work closely related to my specialty or take a broad spectrum approach? I have no strong personal preference here.
  Should I prefer depth (fewer, more hours) assignments or breadth (multiple, fewer hours, perhaps get a wider perspective)?
  What are some ways I can look for clients I can provide the greatest value to, other than engaging my network, especially for the specialist work?
  How do I price the work? Do I charge by time/sub-project tasks/whole projects? How would I determine the rates to charge?
  If I have about two months until I can start working on this business, what are the most impactful preparations I can make?
I expect a lot of these questions are best answered by an "it depends", so my goal is to build the mental framework to attack them, and would appreciate any help.

Ask HN: Why haven't bookmarks been re-invented?
text: Perhaps I'm not in the know, but I find it hard to imagine that we encounter a site, we bookmark it into what's often a poorly self-curated / organized taxonomy, and then rarely ever go back to it, what do other people do to manage their bookmarks, or to even share them? I love "awesome lists" as well, which are often just a bunch of well organized bookmarks anyways, so what do people do that's better than this?
